posts.cooked: Hey, I’ve been looking at 1323’s differential wrist but can’t really wrap my head around how it works. I get that there is a set of gears on the outside and then another on the inside, and that if both motors spin the same speed and direction then one will move, and if they are going in opposite directions then the other will move, because one set is the difference of both motors. However, I don’t understand how this difference make one set of gears or the other move. Are the inner gears dead axled? Are they also connected to both motors? How?

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: See Differential Elevator Design - #5 by dydx

Tbh you should feel free to ask this excellent question in the 1323 thread! Some of the CAD renders may help.

1323 - 2025 Tech Binder Technical

There are two connected sets of bevels in madtowns wrist setup, the differential mechanism consists of 3 bevel gears and controls the wrist movement and rotation. The second set of bevels (2 gears) powers a set of rollers that are on the wrist coaxially, so there is a deadaxle setup. The smaller set of gears don’t have any weight on the wrist movement and are just a way to power the rollers without adding another motor to the moving part of the wrist.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked: It’s a valid explanation of how differentials work, it’s just packaged a bit differently.
